articles.headline: A Forecast for a Fork in the Road
articles.snippet: The Economic Cycle Research Institute was among the first to predict the recession after the 1990’s boom, and it is getting nervous once again.
articles.abstract: The Economic Cycle Research Institute was among the first to predict the recession after the 1990’s boom, and it is getting nervous once again.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEARLY six years ago, when most forecasters were still whistling past the graveyard, a small outfit in New York known as the Economic Cycle Research Institute said the 1990’s boom was over and made a recession call. With factory orders plummeting and goods piling up in company warehouses, the institute said big job cuts were sure to follow.

articles.headline: Clip and Save Holds Its Own Against Point and Click
articles.snippet: Tradition and decades of consumer expectations are, for now, helping paper coupons survive online competition.
articles.abstract: Tradition and decades of consumer expectations are, for now, helping paper coupons survive online competition.
articles.lead_paragraph: In an Internet age, it would seem to be a scene from the past. But for Kristine Davis, as for millions of shoppers across the country, it remains a Sunday morning ritual: retrieving the newspaper from the driveway and quickly extracting the coupon inserts.

articles.headline: Kraft Foods Is Inching to a Spinoff
articles.snippet: Kraft Foods wants to spin off from the Altria Group and be free of what many Kraft employees refer to as the “tobacco taint.”
articles.abstract: Kraft Foods wants to spin off from the Altria Group and be free of what many Kraft employees refer to as the “tobacco taint.”
articles.lead_paragraph: When the World Health Organization held meetings in Geneva with the food industry to discuss the growing problem of worldwide obesity last year, all the major food companies were there — except one.

articles.headline: Bush Repeats Vow to Help New Orleans
articles.snippet: President Bush said he took “full responsibility” for the slow federal response to the disaster as he made a choreographed trip to the city that suffered most.
articles.abstract: President Bush said he took “full responsibility” for the slow federal response to the disaster as he made a choreographed trip to the city that suffered most.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 29 — Still at pains a year after Hurricane Katrina to demonstrate his concern over the devastation it caused, President Bush said Tuesday that he took “full responsibility” for the slow federal response to the disaster as he made a carefully choreographed pilgrimage to the city that suffered most.
articles.byline: By ANNE KORNBLUT and ADAM NOSSITER

articles.headline: In Chechen’s Humiliation, Questions on Rule of Law
articles.snippet: Chechen security forces’ brutish acts, such as the torture of a woman accused of adultery, have gone unpunished.
articles.abstract: Chechen security forces’ brutish acts, such as the torture of a woman accused of adultery, have gone unpunished.
articles.lead_paragraph: ARGUN, Russia, Aug. 26 — The humiliation of Malika Soltayeva, a pregnant Chechen woman suspected of adultery, was ferocious and swift.

articles.headline: Census Reports Slight Increase in ’05 Incomes
articles.snippet: The rise was not attributed to bigger paychecks, but rather more family members taking jobs and investment income.
articles.abstract: The rise was not attributed to bigger paychecks, but rather more family members taking jobs and investment income.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation’s median household income rose slightly faster than inflation last year for the first time in six years, the Census Bureau reported yesterday.

articles.headline: U.S. Seeks Bigger China Role in I.M.F.
articles.snippet: In an effort to gain economic cooperation, the U.S. is pushing for China and other developing nations to get more power.
articles.abstract: In an effort to gain economic cooperation, the U.S. is pushing for China and other developing nations to get more power.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 — In an effort to gain Chinese cooperation on international economic issues, the Bush administration is pushing for China and other developing nations to get more power in the global institution that has played a central role in easing myriad financial crises since the end of World War II.

articles.headline: Fed’s Notes See Easing in Growth
articles.snippet: The minutes of the Federal Reserve’s Aug. 8 meeting showed a general expectation that the economy would perform at a sub-par level through next year.
articles.abstract: The minutes of the Federal Reserve’s Aug. 8 meeting showed a general expectation that the economy would perform at a sub-par level through next year.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve’s policy makers, in what many described as a “close call,” chose to keep interest rates unchanged at their last meeting although several thought that increases “could well be needed” in the future.

articles.headline: A Forecast for a Fork in the Road
articles.snippet: NEARLY six years ago, when most forecasters were still whistling past the graveyard, a small outfit in New York known as the Economic Cycle Research Institute said the 1990's boom was over and made a recession call. With factory orders plummeting ...
articles.abstract: NEARLY six years ago, when most forecasters were still whistling past the graveyard, a small outfit in New York known as the Economic Cycle Research Institute said the 1990's boom was over and made a recession call. With factory orders plummeting and goods piling up in company warehouses, the institute said big job cuts were sure to follow.     It was a pretty gutsy move at the time. Alan Greenspan, then the Federal Reserve chairman, and just about every major Wall Street firm were saying in early 2001 that the Fed's aggressive interest rate cuts would lift consumer spending and prevent a recession. In truth, one had already begun.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEARLY six years ago, when most forecasters were still whistling past the graveyard, a small outfit in New York known as the Economic Cycle Research Institute said the 1990's boom was over and made a recession call. With factory orders plummeting and goods piling up in company warehouses, the institute said big job cuts were sure to follow.

articles.headline: In Chechen’s Humiliation, Questions on Rule of Law
articles.snippet: The humiliation of Malika Soltayeva, a pregnant Chechen woman suspected of adultery, was ferocious and swift.      Ms. Soltayeva, 23, had been away from home for a month and was reported missing by her family. When she returned, her husband accuse...
articles.abstract: The humiliation of Malika Soltayeva, a pregnant Chechen woman suspected of adultery, was ferocious and swift.      Ms. Soltayeva, 23, had been away from home for a month and was reported missing by her family. When she returned, her husband accused her of infidelity and banished her from their apartment. The local authorities found her at her aunt's residence. They said they had a few questions.
articles.lead_paragraph: ARGUN, Russia, Aug. 26 - The humiliation of Malika Soltayeva, a pregnant Chechen woman suspected of adultery, was ferocious and swift.

articles.headline: Bush Repeats Vow to Help New Orleans
articles.snippet: Still at pains a year after Hurricane Katrina to demonstrate his concern over the devastation it caused, President Bush said Tuesday that he took ''full responsibility'' for the slow federal response to the disaster as he made a carefully choreogr...
articles.abstract: Still at pains a year after Hurricane Katrina to demonstrate his concern over the devastation it caused, President Bush said Tuesday that he took ''full responsibility'' for the slow federal response to the disaster as he made a carefully choreographed pilgrimage to the city that suffered most.      As bells rang out through the streets, citizens gathered for prayer services and residents hung banners in front of their tattered homes to commemorate the anniversary of the storm, Mr. Bush sought to do what he had not accomplished a year earlier: Demonstrate the depth of his understanding of the emotional and physical toll the hurricane took on New Orleans.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 29 - Still at pains a year after Hurricane Katrina to demonstrate his concern over the devastation it caused, President Bush said Tuesday that he took "full responsibility" for the slow federal response to the disaster as he made a carefully choreographed pilgrimage to the city that suffered most.
articles.byline: By Anne Kornblut and Adam Nossiter

articles.headline: U.S. Seeks Bigger China Role in I.M.F.
articles.snippet: In an effort to gain Chinese cooperation on international economic issues, the Bush administration is pushing for China and other developing nations to get more power in the global institution that has played a central role in easing myriad financ...
articles.abstract: In an effort to gain Chinese cooperation on international economic issues, the Bush administration is pushing for China and other developing nations to get more power in the global institution that has played a central role in easing myriad financial crises since the end of World War II.     But the American-led effort to increase influence at the International Monetary Fund for China -- and for South Korea, Turkey and Mexico, as well -- is being resisted by several countries in Europe, which would lose power to those who would be gaining it.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 - In an effort to gain Chinese cooperation on international economic issues, the Bush administration is pushing for China and other developing nations to get more power in the global institution that has played a central role in easing myriad financial crises since the end of World War II.

articles.headline: Women Suddenly Scarce Among Justices’ Clerks
articles.snippet: Everyone knows that with the retirement of Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, the number of female Supreme Court justices fell by half. The talk of the court this summer, with the arrival of the new crop of law clerks, is that the number of female clerk...
articles.abstract: Everyone knows that with the retirement of Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, the number of female Supreme Court justices fell by half. The talk of the court this summer, with the arrival of the new crop of law clerks, is that the number of female clerks has fallen even more sharply.     Just under 50 percent of new law school graduates in 2005 were women. Yet women account for only 7 of the 37 law clerkships for the new term, the first time the number has been in the single digits since 1994, when there were 4,000 fewer women among the country's new law school graduates than there are today.

articles.headline: Clip and Save Holds Its Own Against Point and Click
articles.snippet: In an Internet age, it would seem to be a scene from the past. But for Kristine Davis, as for millions of shoppers across the country, it remains a Sunday morning ritual: retrieving the newspaper from the driveway and quickly extracting the coupon...
articles.abstract: In an Internet age, it would seem to be a scene from the past. But for Kristine Davis, as for millions of shoppers across the country, it remains a Sunday morning ritual: retrieving the newspaper from the driveway and quickly extracting the coupon inserts.      By shrewdly using coupons, and tracking store sales, Ms. Davis says she can cut the monthly grocery bill by 30 or 40 percent for her family of four in Marietta, Ga., a suburb of Atlanta.
articles.lead_paragraph: In an Internet age, it would seem to be a scene from the past. But for Kristine Davis, as for millions of shoppers across the country, it remains a Sunday morning ritual: retrieving the newspaper from the driveway and quickly extracting the coupon inserts.

articles.headline: Broadcast Chief Misused Office, Inquiry Reports
articles.snippet: State Department investigators have found that the head of the agency overseeing most government broadcasts to foreign countries has used his office to run a ''horse racing operation'' and that he improperly put a friend on the payroll, according ...
articles.abstract: State Department investigators have found that the head of the agency overseeing most government broadcasts to foreign countries has used his office to run a ''horse racing operation'' and that he improperly put a friend on the payroll, according to a summary of a report made public on Tuesday by a Democratic lawmaker.     The report said that the official, Kenneth Y. Tomlinson, had repeatedly used government employees to perform personal errands and that he billed the government for more days of work than the rules permit.

articles.headline: Kraft Foods Is Inching to a Spinoff
articles.snippet: When the World Health Organization held meetings in Geneva with the food industry to discuss the growing problem of worldwide obesity last year, all the major food companies were there -- except one.      That company, Kraft Foods, the world's sec...
articles.abstract: When the World Health Organization held meetings in Geneva with the food industry to discuss the growing problem of worldwide obesity last year, all the major food companies were there -- except one.      That company, Kraft Foods, the world's second-largest packaged-food company, after Nestlé, was not invited because its parent owns a tobacco company, a type of business the W.H.O. refuses to deal with.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the World Health Organization held meetings in Geneva with the food industry to discuss the growing problem of worldwide obesity last year, all the major food companies were there -- except one.

articles.headline: Fed’s Notes See Easing in Growth
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve's policy makers, in what many described as a ''close call,'' chose to keep interest rates unchanged at their last meeting although several thought that increases ''could well be needed'' in the future.     The much-anticipated ...
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve's policy makers, in what many described as a ''close call,'' chose to keep interest rates unchanged at their last meeting although several thought that increases ''could well be needed'' in the future.     The much-anticipated minutes of the Aug. 8 meeting, released yesterday, showed that the policy makers were hoping that a slowing economy, a deteriorating housing market and the accumulating impact of previous rate increases had mitigated the need for still higher interest rates to control inflation. Indeed, the minutes showed a general expectation that the economy would perform at a sub-par level through next year.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve's policy makers, in what many described as a "close call," chose to keep interest rates unchanged at their last meeting although several thought that increases "could well be needed" in the future.

articles.headline: Census Reports Slight Increase in ’05 Incomes
articles.snippet: The nation's median household income rose slightly faster than inflation last year for the first time in six years, the Census Bureau reported yesterday.     The rise, however, had little to do with bigger paychecks -- in fact, both men and women ...
articles.abstract: The nation's median household income rose slightly faster than inflation last year for the first time in six years, the Census Bureau reported yesterday.     The rise, however, had little to do with bigger paychecks -- in fact, both men and women earned less in 2005 than 2004. Rather, census officials said, more family members were taking jobs to make ends meet, and some people made more money from investments and other sources beyond wages.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation's median household income rose slightly faster than inflation last year for the first time in six years, the Census Bureau reported yesterday.
